> http://www.cse.ogi.edu/PacSoft/conf/jvw02/

I just read this paper (in 5 minutes so forgive me if I haven't got 
everything).  Here's a really short review:

- the general idea is to generate JUnit tests from pre- and 
postconditions embedded into the code and written in JML
- the user supply "reasonable" test inputs [...] by subclassing and 
redefining the setUp method of generated TestCase classes

In theory, this seems practical but I doubt that this will survive a 
real world project.  Some reasons:

- subclassing and redefining the setUp method means to each time create 
a new TestCase subclass.  I can easily imagine loosing the overview

- writing postconditions is not trivial and certainly harder than 
writing standard tests.  Since TestCases are generated from these 
postconditions, I imagine that the normal process is
     1) write postcondition with JML
     2) generate tests
     3) it fails.  But is the error in JML or in code?
     4) check the generated tests, the JML pre/postconditions and the 
code, goto 2)
    I'm not convinced that this is the fastest way to write tests

- In their code, I see the famous:
      catch (JMLAssertionException e) {
         fail(e.getMessage());
      }
   which makes me wonder...  can they debug without any stack trace?

- you have to learn another language JML and successfully writing tests 
implies that you master JML.  How do you know that you master JML if you 
can't test your JML code?

- the example is _*trivial*_.  Testing is not an easy task (that's why 
you have mock objects, db connections, etc...) so why are the example so 
trivial?  At least I would like to see the testing of exceptions and 
strings.

I understand that this is a research paper and from what I've read, the 
authors have yet to test their method on a larger project.  I'm not 
very convinced by their method.  I'm open but first would like to see 
some real life examples.

-Vladimir

PS: JML is hosted on sourceforge (jmlspecs).

-- 
Vladimir R. Bossicard
